article.title: I'm 52 and thought I'd be financially secure by now. But I'm still facing debt and long-term unemployment.
article.summary:

Courtesy of Dana Lee JonesThe author is still financially struggling in her 50s.
Instead, at 52, I'm still struggling financially and facing debt.
My career felt solid.
Many contractors like me did not receive back pay, and each day without work felt like slipping into the same uncertainty I was still clawing my way out of.

With the uh if we see some uh a surge in this economy, the Fed may not have to do anything, right?
But when you consider that small businesses are still going to be, you know, trying to access bank loans with revolving rates and they're, you know, they're subject to interest rate risk.
I think that a few cuts, one or two, maybe one in March, one in June would really start to get things going.

On my first day at the restaurant, I learned how to run the door, be a hostess, serve, and run private events.

article.title: How banning big investors from buying homes could affect prices
article.summary:
Industry watchers on both sides of the aisle say President Donald Trump's recently announced goal of banning "large institutional investors" from buying single-family homes won't address the root cause of high home prices: a shortage of homes.
In the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, large investors bought thousands of distressed properties, particularly in Southeastern cities.
And since 2022, large investors have slowed their purchasing as interest rates have spiked and home prices have remained high.
Some major investors have shifted their business model to buying homes in bulk directly from homebuilders, rather than purchasing them one by one.
Fairweather agreed that banning large landlords from owning single-family homes would mean fewer tenants could live in these wealthier neighborhoods.

article.title: America Had Its Worst Non-Recession Jobs Year Since 2003
article.summary:
ICE and CPB’s racist operations, more than any other policy of Trump 2, are harming economic growth, according to the last legitimate Chair of the Federal Reserve.
Trump is throwing that all into question, making us look more like Europe and Japan; older, less dynamic societies with a cap on intrinsic economic growth.
Trump also wants to lower interest rates to around 1% or less, essentially making that a requirement of the next Fed Chair.
What the 1970s taught us is that there is good economic growth and bad economic “growth,” called inflation.
It is very possible that Trump drops the Fed Funds Rate to 1%, and broader interest rates rise in response.

article.title: Looking for a Job? These Cities Are Leading the Way in 2026

MORE THAN A PAYCHECKWalletHubThere are two key drivers when it comes to uncovering the cities with the best job opportunities in 2026: market and socioeconomic factors.
According to WalletHub, job market factors to consider when searching for your next best role include employment growth, average monthly salary, unemployment rates, job security, job satisfaction, and access to benefits and retirement options.
Columbia, Maryland, quietly dominates with promising employment growth, affordable rent and housing, and exceptional job security.
Down South, Orlando, Florida, is not just tourists and theme parks; it's a thriving job market paired with no state income tax, which is always a plus.
This metropolis reported robust job growth from 2024 to 2026 across multiple specialties and annual median wages that align with the rising cost of living.

Hiring slows in December to end the weakest year of job growth since the pandemictoggle caption Spencer Platt/Getty Images North AmericaHiring remained anemic in December, closing out the weakest year for job growth since the beginning of the pandemic.
For all of 2025, employers added 584,000 jobs — compared to 2 million new jobs in 2024.
The federal government added 2,000 jobs in December, but is still down 277,000 jobs from the beginning of the year.
The government recorded big job losses earlier in the fall, when workers who accepted buyouts officially dropped off the government's payroll.
Concern about the weakening job market prompted the Federal Reserve to cut its benchmark interest rate in December for the third time since September.

article.title: Disney CEO meets top Chinese official as 'House of Mouse' navigates US‑China tensions
article.summary:
BEIJING, Jan 9 (Reuters) - One of China's top officials met with Disney CEO Bob Iger in Beijing on Friday, state media ​reported, as the "House of Mouse" seeks to strengthen its foothold ‌in the world's second-largest economy amid fraught U.S.-China tensions.
For three decades, Beijing has capped Hollywood imports at just 10 films a year, and it has made significant headway in steering Chinese audiences toward domestically produced movies in the world's second-largest film market.
Chinese moviegoers propelled "Ne Zha 2" past Pixar's "Inside Out 2" to make it the ⁠highest‑grossing animated film of all time last ​year.
Hollywood films account for only 5% of ​overall box office receipts in China's markets, analysts estimate.
"Disney is full of confidence in China's development and will continue to expand investment in ‌China," Iger was quoted as saying.

Selling PHEV models would help Zeekr avoid European Union tariffs ‍on Chinese-made fully-electric cars.
Zeekr currently sells in 12 European markets and launched in Germany in December - and in some markets sells directly to consumers.

Proponents of prediction markets argue putting money on the line leads to better forecasts.
Still, it's never a “crystal ball,” he noted, and prediction markets can be wrong, too.
Loose regulationBecause they’re positioned as selling event contracts, prediction markets are regulated by the CFTC.

article.title: Canadian economy added 8,200 jobs in December, while unemployment rose to 6.8%
article.summary:
Statistics Canada says a boost in the number of people looking for work in December drove the unemployment rate higher at the end of the year.
Canada created just 8,200 new jobs in December, while the unemployment rate rose to 6.8 per cent, up from 6.5 per cent the month before.
December's job gains were concentrated in full-time work, which added 50,200 jobs in December, while part-time ‍employment fell ⁠by 42,000.
Douglas Porter, BMO's chief economist, said the December figures bring job gains back to a more "realistic place."
Friday's jobs report marks the Bank of Canada's last look at the state of the labour market before its first interest-rate decision of the year later this month.

article.title: Elon Musk: Saving for Retirement 'Irrelevant' in Abundant Future
article.summary:
Saving for retirement has been a cornerstone of personal finance for well over a century.
"If any of the things that we've said are true, saving for retirement will be irrelevant," Musk added.
The "good future is anyone can have whatever stuff they want," Musk said.
Despite his track record, Musk's latest prediction clashes hard with the reality faced by many Americans.
A comfortable retirement also feels out of reach, with surveys showing the majority of Americans aren't saving nearly enough.

Because of the mobility of rich people, California does have real worries about the impact of a state wealth tax.

A few years ago, some tech people moved to Miami, claiming it was going to become the new Silicon Valley.

In short, he wants to build the next Funko Pops, but make it AI.
Instead of selling figurines, Buddyo is launching a stand it calls an AI Pod, with a slot the exact size of a standard Amiibo base.
It’s still an open question whether there’s a meaningful market for AI toys and chatbot companions, but combining the tech with collectibles is the most convincing case I’ve seen yet.

article.title: This Atitan Bluetooth transceiver can bring Auracast to Apple iPhones
article.summary:
One of the issues holding Auracast back from wider mainstream use is some companies’ lack of support for the Bluetooth technology — Apple being a prime example.
As of yet, Apple has made no comment on Auracast, and I’m not hopeful that we’ll get one anytime soon.
It’s developing a small disc-shaped transceiver — the splitR — that can attach to an iPhone’s MagSafe and turn it into an Auracast device capable of either transmitting or receiving an Auracast broadcast.
The splitR isn’t meant just for an Apple device, though.
And Atitan tells me the next iteration will be able to pair wirelessly to translate a classic Bluetooth connection into a Bluetooth LE Auracast transmission.

article.title: The latest on Grok’s gross AI deepfakes problem
article.summary:
The launch of an AI image editing feature on xAI’s Grok has caused chaos on X after it was used to generate a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes.
As Hayden Field wrote , “screenshots show Grok complying with requests to put real women in lingerie and make them spread their legs, and to put small children in bikinis.”UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer called the deepfakes “disgusting,” saying, “X need[s] to get their act together and get this material down.
And we will take action on this because it’s simply not tolerable.” X has slightly restricted the feature by requiring a paid subscription to generate images by tagging Grok on X, but the AI image editor remains freely available otherwise.

article.title: Why boosting production of Venezuela's 'very dense, very sloppy' oil could harm the environment

Venezuela's oil reserves are thought to be the largest in the world at an estimated 300 billion barrels.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementEven a modest increase in Venezuelan oil production could carry climate consequences on the scale of entire countries, said Mahdavi, of the University of California, Santa Barbara.
He said Venezuela’s heavy oil reserves lie in fragile plains crisscrossed by slow-moving rivers, a geography that can magnify the effects of spills.
The true environmental and social costs of Venezuela’s oil have never been fully calculated, de Lisio said.

article.title: The Oceans Just Keep Getting Hotter
article.summary:
Since 2018, a group of researchers from around the world have crunched the numbers on how much heat the world’s oceans are absorbing each year.
In 2025, their measurements broke records once again, making this the eighth year in a row that the world’s oceans have absorbed more heat than the years before.
While some of the excess heat warms the ocean’s surface, it also slowly travels further down into deeper parts of the ocean, aided by circulation and currents.
Global temperature calculations—like the ones used to determine the hottest years on record—usually only capture measurements taken at the ocean’s surface.
While sea surface temperatures have risen since the industrial revolution, thanks to our use of fossil fuels, these measurements don’t provide a full picture of how climate change is affecting the oceans.

"Sandy and mostly devoid of life, the Kubuqi Desert in Inner Mongolia once had a reputation for being a 'sea of death.'

The Three Gorges Kubuqi Solar Park, due to be completed in 2030, will be 250 miles long, three miles wide, and will be able to generate 100 gigawatts of clean energy.

article.title: Ford Stored Unsold Mavericks Underground in Kansas City During 1970s Sales Slump
article.summary:
During the 1970s, Ford Motor Company took an unconventional approach to managing surplus inventory by storing unsold vehicles deep underground beneath Kansas City.
As market conditions shifted and sales slowed, Ford found itself with thousands of unsold Mavericks occupying dealership space and storage lots.
Compared with surface storage, the underground environment lowered long-term storage costs and preserved vehicle condition while Ford evaluated its next steps.
By storing completed vehicles underground, Ford effectively bought time to redistribute inventory or sell cars later once demand stabilized.
Rather than forcing rapid discounting or scrapping new vehicles, Ford used the underground storage as a buffer against shifting consumer demand.

article.summary:

However, "Greenland" differs from the usual disaster movie formula by telling a genuinely harrowing story that explores how humanity would react to, and suffer from, a catastrophic event.
"Greenland 2: Migration" continues to showcase the bleaker side of disaster fare — and it's even more brutal than its predecessor.
Directed by Ric Roman Waugh from a script by Chris Sparling and Mitchell LaFortune, "Greenland 2: Migration" combines disaster movie thrills with post-apocalyptic savagery.
On paper, "Greenland 2: Migration" sounds like every other post-apocalyptic disaster movie.

article.title: Ocean Temperatures Just Hit a Dire New Record
article.summary:
The world’s ocean absorbed more heat in 2025 than in any other year on recordThe oceans just keep getting hotter.
According to new research from dozens of international scientists published in Advances in Atmospheric Sciences early on Friday, the world’s oceans stored more heat in 2025 than any other year on record.
In 2025 the upper 2,000 meters of the ocean absorbed a record-setting 23 zettajoules more energy than in 2024.
These hot surface temperatures are a factor in Earth’s overall annual surface temperature; 2025 is expected to be the second- or third-hottest year on record.
Hotter oceans contribute to rising sea levels, disrupt fragile marine ecosystems and fuel extreme weather.

The video demonstrates that the officers didn't perceive Good to be a threat, said John P. Gross, a professor at the University of Wisconsin Law School who has written extensively about officers shooting at moving vehicles.

article.title: Colombia sees 'real threat' of US military action, president tells BBC
article.summary:
Colombia sees 'real threat' of US military action, president tells BBC4 days ago Share Save Ione Wells BBC South America Correspondent, in Bogotá Share SaveWatch: BBC speaks to Colombian President Gustavo PetroColombia's President Gustavo Petro has told the BBC that he believes there is now a "real threat" of US military action against Colombia.
It comes after Trump said a military operation in Colombia "sounds good".
Following US strikes on Venezuela and the seizure of Nicolás Maduro, US President Donald Trump said a military operation targeting Colombia "sounds good".
After Trump's comments threatening military action in Colombia, demonstrations were held across the country in the name of sovereignty and democracy.
Petro confirmed he had also spoken to Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela's acting president and former vice president and oil minister, and invited her to Colombia.

article.title: Border Patrol Agents Shoot 2 During Traffic Stop
article.summary:
U.S. federal agents shot two people in Portland, Oregon, on Thursday afternoon.
“Two people are in the hospital following a shooting involving federal agents,” Portland police said in a statement.
In a statement, Department of Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said the incident began during a “targeted vehicle stop” by Border Patrol agents.
The FBI said in a statement it was investigating an “assault” involving two Customs and Border Patrol agents.
“Earlier this afternoon, two people were injured by federal agents in the Hazelwood neighborhood.

article.title: Nationwide anti-ICE protests call for accountability after Renee Good's death
article.summary:
Nationwide anti-ICE protests call for accountability after Renee Good's deathtoggle caption Spencer Platt/Getty ImagesPeople took to the streets in cities across the country this weekend to protest the Trump administration's immigration enforcement tactics following the death of Renee Good in Minneapolis, a 37-year-old woman who was shot and killed by a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officer last week.
People demonstrated outside of hotels where ICE agents were believed to be staying.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem on Sunday said the agency was sending "hundreds more" federal agents to Minneapolis Sunday and Monday to protect ICE agents.
Good was killed the day after DHS launched a large-scale immigration enforcement operation in Minnesota set to deploy 2,000 immigration officers to the state.
There were no arrests during the protests, a spokesperson for the Metropolitan Police Department told NPR on Sunday.

article.title: Video Cellphone video from officer shows moment leading up to fatal shooting of Renee Good
article.summary: Cellphone video from officer shows moment leading up to fatal shooting of Renee Good Tensions continue to flare in Minneapolis after an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer fatally shot the 37-year-old woman on Wednesday.

article.title: Thousands march and dozens arrested in Minneapolis protests against ICE
article.summary:
Thousands march and dozens arrested in Minneapolis protests against ICE1 day ago Share Save Ana Faguy Share SaveWatch: Thousands march in Minneapolis in protest against ICEThousands of people joined another night of protests in Minneapolis on Saturday, following the death of a woman who was shot by a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agent in the city.
Minneapolis police estimated "tens of thousands of people" attended the "ICE out of Minnesota" rally and march, which started in Powderhorn Park on Saturday.
Watch: Video filmed by ICE agent who shot Minneapolis woman has emergedOfficials said another hotel in the city was also targeted and had window and graffiti damage.
She told CNN that Good had "weaponised" her car" to attack ICE agents in the city of Minneapolis.
The Minneapolis mayor added that the city's local law enforcement were "outnumbered by the number of ICE agents and beyond".

article.title: 'Unhappy' Putin sends message to West with Ukraine strike on EU border
article.summary:
Russia's Oreshnik missile attack in Ukraine near the EU border aims to intimidate Kyiv's Western allies and signals Vladimir Putin's displeasure at recent foreign policy setbacks including in Venezuela, analysts said Friday.
Lviv mayor Andriy Sadovy said on Facebook the strike was "a new level of threat -- not only for Ukraine, but also for the security of Europe".
"This should probably be seen as a message to European countries," he said, adding the result of the strike was "probably more psychological than operational".
Timothy Ash, an emerging market economist focused on Russia, struck a similar note, pointing to relatively limited damage on the ground after the missile strike.
While Russia calls the Oreshnik a hypersonic missile, Western defence analysts say it is not a revolutionary weapon.

article.title: Two hospitalized after shooting involving federal agents in Portland
article.summary:
Two people were hospitalized after a shooting involving Customs and Border Patrol agents in Portland, Oregon, according to officials.
The conditions of the victims are unknown at this time.
NBC News' Dana Griffin has the latest developments.

article.title: Video captures Minneapolis immigration arrest in a city on edge after shooting of Renee Good
article.summary:
In a dramatic scene similar to those playing out across Minneapolis, agents captured a man in the home just minutes after pepper spraying protesters outside who had confronted the heavily armed federal agents.
Video of the clash taken by The Associated Press showed some agents pushing back protesters while a distraught woman later emerged from the house with a document that federal agents presented to arrest the man.
Signed by an immigration officer, the document — unlike a warrant signed by a judge — does not authorize forced entry into a private residence.
A warrant signed by an immigration officer only authorizes arrest in a public area.
“We’re seeing a lot of immigration enforcement across Minneapolis and across the state, federal agents just swarming around our neighborhoods,” said Jason Chavez, a Minneapolis city councilmember.

article.title: CBP Agents Shoots Two In Portland, Listen To Dispatch Audio
article.summary:
The feds say the agent "fired a defensive shot" out of fear for his life and safety ... and the driver fled the scene with his passenger.
DHS also says the alleged gang member here was recently involved in a shooting in Portland.
Another shooting involving federal immigration agents and civilians ... and this time the feds shot two people in Oregon.
Play video content FreedomNews.TVThe Portland shooting comes one day after an ICE agent shot and killed a woman in Minneapolis.
Portland is not a 'training ground' for militarized agents, and the 'full force' threatened by the administration has deadly consequences.

article.title: The violent “randomness” of ICE’s deportation campaign
article.summary:
And what specifically changed in the way ICE operates domestically?
I put these questions to David Hausman, a UC Berkeley School of Law assistant professor and the faculty director of the Deportation Data Project, a database of individual-level immigration enforcement cases.
How does domestic immigration enforcement now compare to how it used to work before Trump?
Before this current administration and going back to at least the first Obama administration, ICE was really an agency that didn’t conduct many arrests.
And as a result, ICE arrests out in the community were very, very rare.

article.title: ICE Wasn’t Always Like This
article.summary:
On Wednesday, an ICE officer shot and killed Renee Nicole Good, a mother of three and a U.S. citizen, in the streets of Minneapolis.
As my colleague Caitlin Dickerson explains in her latest story, the president and his advisers have exerted “overwhelming pressure” on immigration enforcement.
Will Gottsegen: To what extent is ICE no longer subject to some of the guardrails that once helped keep it in check?
The pressure that ICE officers are facing is unprecedented, and it’s not just the pressure to carry out as many deportations as possible—the administration is actually celebrating aggression.
Will: How does this pressure on ICE officers affect immigration-enforcement operations?

article.title: The pope in a major foreign policy address blasts how countries are using force to assert dominion
article.summary:
“War is back in vogue and a zeal for war is spreading,” Leo told ambassadors from around the world who represent their countries’ interests at the Holy See.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementThe occasion was the pope’s annual audience with the Vatican diplomatic corps, which traditionally amounts to his yearly foreign policy address.
In his first such encounter, history’s first U.S.-born pope delivered much more than the traditional roundup of global hotspots.
“The principle established after the Second World War, which prohibited nations from using force to violate the borders of others, has been completely undermined.”“Instead, peace is sought through weapons as a condition for asserting one’s own dominion.
___Associated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP’s collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc.

article.title: France swaps alleged ransomware crook for conflict researche
article.summary:
France has released an alleged ransomware crook wanted by the US in exchange for a conflict researcher imprisoned in Russia.
Specializing in the Ukraine war, Vinatier's work focused on communicating between states mired in conflict, outside of official channels.
Kasatkin, 26, was accused of aiding ransomware negotiations between a major, unnamed cybercrime outfit and around 900 victims, including two US federal departments.
On August 1, 2024, the largest exchange of prisoners since the Cold War took place between Russia and the West.
Twenty-four individuals were freed in total: 16 for the West, and eight Russians, including several cybercriminals and state assassin Vadim Krasikov.

article.title: Yemen completes evacuation of stranded tourists on Socotra island
article.summary:
Jan 10 (Reuters) - Yemen completed on Saturday the evacuation of more than ​600 tourists who had been ‌stranded on the remote Yemeni island of Socotra ‌after the United Arab Emirates withdrew its troops from Yemen last week amid a rift with Saudi Arabia.
Four flights ⁠operated by Yemenia ‌Airways, Yemen's national carrier, transported 609 tourists to Saudi Arabia's ‍city of Jeddah, the Yemeni Foreign Ministry said in a statement.
Air traffic at the ​island's main airport came to a ‌halt as a deepening crisis between the UAE and Saudi Arabia translated into fresh conflict on Yemen's mainland, where the two Gulf powers now back ⁠opposing groups in the ​country's civil war.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementSocotra, which ​lies more than 300 km (186 miles) south of Yemen's coast and ‍until recently ⁠was mainly accessible by air via the UAE, has been a haven ⁠of tranquillity through the years of conflict ‌on the mainland.
(Reporting by Hatem MaherEditing ‌by Mark Potter)

article.title: Is Donald Trump Creating the Conditions for Another World War?
article.summary:
Listen and subscribe: Apple | Spotify | Google | Wherever You ListenSign up to receive our twice-weekly News & Politics newsletter.
The Washington Roundtable discusses Donald Trump’s use of force in Venezuela, his desire to take over Greenland, and the historical echoes of the Administration’s new imperialist projects.
The panel also considers Trump’s brand of “narcissistic unilateralism” and the increased risks of global conflict when foreign policy is based on one man’s whims.
“Donald Trump wants to write his name into history,” the staff writer Susan B. Glasser says.
“He wants every single person in the world to have to exchange their map for one of the United States that looks different, that looks bigger, and that everybody for all eternity will say, ‘Donald Trump did this.’ ”This week’s reading:“Why Donald Trump Wants Greenland (and Everything Else),” by Susan B. Glasser“Minneapolis Grieves, Again,” by E. Tammy Kim“What Will Become of Venezuela’s Political Prisoners?,” by Stephania Taladrid“The Dramatic Arraignment of Nicolás Maduro,” by Cristian Farias“The Former Trump Skeptics Getting Behind His War in Venezuela,” by Isaac Chotiner“Jack Smith’s Closing Argument,” by Ruth Marcus“Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Big Breakup,” by Charles BetheaTune in to The Political Scene wherever you get your podcasts.

article.title: What Trump's vision of the new world order means for Europe
article.summary:
America led the creation of Nato, the World Bank, the IMF and the United Nations.
"The degree to which control of the canal is necessary to the United States cannot be overstated."
Under the new strategy, the United States will no longer pressure authoritarian regimes to improve their human rights records.
And one of its policies for doing this is by "cultivating resistance to Europe's current trajectory within European nations".
"The Europeans have become very dependent upon the United States, and this was a matter of choice: it was cheaper and simpler.

article.title: Trump’s Foreign Policy Madness Will Haunt Us for Generations
article.summary:
Some officials described it as a “law enforcement operation,” citing a 2020 federal grand jury indictment against Maduro.
Others suggested that the Trump administration would now try to now control the rest of the New World more aggressively.
Trump and his top officials have threatened additional military action in Colombia, Cuba, and Mexico.
As many as 73 percent of voters oppose the use of military force to seize Greenland, according to one post-Maduro poll.
Trump sits atop the executive branch, which is little more than a vehicle for his personal whims and desires.

article.title: Iran medics describe hospitals overwhelmed with dead and injured protesters
article.summary:
'There wasn't even time for CPR': Iran medics describe hospitals overwhelmed with dead and injured protesters2 days ago Share Save Soroush Pakzad , Roja Assadi , BBC News Persian, and Helen Sullivan Share SaveWatch: Government building on fire as protests continue in Karaj, IranStaff at several hospitals in Iran have told the BBC their facilities are overwhelmed with dead or injured patients, as major anti-government protests continue.
Reacting to the latest developments, President Trump posted on social media: "Iran is looking at FREEDOM, perhaps like never before.
Hundreds of protesters are believed to have been killed or injured, and many more detained.
A doctor at a medical centre in Tehran told the BBC: "The number of injured people and fatalities was very high.
But former UK ambassador to Iran Sir Simon Gass told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that "we really shouldn't get too ahead of ourselves" when discussing regime change.

article.title: Why is Pakistan selling its JF-17 fighter jets to Bangladesh and others?
article.summary:
Islamabad’s defence diplomacy is driving new interest in the JF-17 fighter jet following Pakistan-India clashes.
Before the JF-17, Pakistan was primarily relying on French manufacturer Dassault’s Mirage III and Mirage 5, as well as Chinese J-7 fighter planes.
The Pakistan Air Force says the jet offers high manoeuvrability at medium and low altitudes and combines firepower, agility and survivability, making it “a potent platform for any air force”.
With the plane’s entire assembly carried out in Kamra, Pakistan is the primary seller of the JF-17 fighter plane, including its after-sales services.
Fighter jets, he added, are a long-term commitment, with service lives of three to four decades.

article.title: Why is the US quitting international organisations?
article.summary:
There are more signs that the United States is disengaging from the global order established after World War II.
President Donald Trump has ordered his administration to pull out of more than 60 agencies, half of them part of the United Nations.
Trump argues that being a member of these organisations is contrary to his country’s interests.
This move has prompted global outrage, with the UN saying its ‘responsibility to deliver’ will not waver.
Presenter: James BaysGuests:Adolfo Franco – Republican strategist and former adviser to US Senator John McCainAndrew Gilmour – Former UN assistant secretary-general for human rightsMatthew Duss – Executive VP of the Center for International Policy and a former foreign policy adviser to Senator Bernie Sanders
